metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: The multi-scale observation experiment on evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (MUSOEXE-12)-dataset of flux observation matrix (eddy covariance system of Daman superstation lower)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Daman superstation eddy covariance system (EC) at the lowest layer in the flux observation matrix from 25 May to 15 September, 2012. The site (100.37223° E, 38.85551° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556.06 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.5 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.17 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Verification.Question: Is there a multiscale dataset available that includes both ground-based and airborne remote sensing data for eco-hydrological research?
Are there data collection methods that involve quality control measures such as sensor calibration and data processing?

Disjunctive.Question: Which method is more effective for measuring soil and canopy component temperatures, a high-resolution thermal camera or traditional radiometers?
What is a more significant challenge in estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes, multiscale observation availability or composite temperature separation?

Concept Completion.Question: What are some data collection methods used to measure evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Concept Completion.Answer: Eddy covariance systems, four-component radiometers, thermal infrared cameras

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the flux observation matrix data, related to evapotranspiration and eco-hydrological processes, typically collected?
What challenges are faced in collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes?

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced when collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research is the poor availability of multiscale observation data, which hinders the upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface. This was addressed by the HiWATER experiment, which aimed to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes through instruments arranged in hierarchically nested scales.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset used to analyze evapotranspiration over an oasis-desert area?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to analyze evapotranspiration over an oasis-desert area is the multiscale dataset from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) conducted in 2012. It includes data from a flux observation matrix, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing missions, which were used to study eco-hydrological processes in the oasis-desert interaction.

How many intensive observation periods (IOPs) were conducted during the HiWATER experiment in 2012?
Quantification.Answer: The exact number is not specified.

Quantification.Question: What is the elevation of the Daman superstation where the meteorological parameters were measured?

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for evapotranspiration estimation using eddy covariance systems compare to those using thermal infrared cameras in terms of accuracy and application in heterogeneous landscapes?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance system provides direct measurements of evapotranspiration but may face challenges in achieving energy balance closure in heterogeneous landscapes. In contrast, using thermal infrared cameras allows for the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures, which can improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates by addressing the advective conditions present in these landscapes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data quality control measures between datasets obtained from ground-based eddy covariance systems and those from airborne remote sensing platforms in eco-hydrological studies?
Comparison.Answer: Data from eddy covariance systems undergo quality control measures such as outlier removal, delay correction, and stability testing to ensure accuracy. In contrast, airborne remote sensing data involve sensor calibration, classification accuracy checks, and atmospheric corrections to account for errors in pixel classification and radiation estimates, particularly in heterogeneous landscapes.

Interpretation.Question: How can the quality assessment criteria used in data processing, such as atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, enhance the reliability of flux measurements in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: The quality assessment criteria, including atmospheric stability (Δst) and turbulence similarity characteristics (ITC), are crucial in evaluating the reliability of flux measurements. They help in filtering out measurements that are likely to be inaccurate due to unstable atmospheric conditions or weak turbulence, which is especially important in heterogeneous landscapes where such conditions can greatly affect data quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the poor availability of multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The poor availability of multiscale observations is a significant challenge due to the complexity and variability of heterogeneous surfaces, which require a hierarchically nested scale approach to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes effectively.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do errors occur in the derived component temperature when using thermal imaging for soil and canopy temperature estimation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in the derived component temperature occur primarily due to image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. These errors lead to overestimation of canopy temperature and uncertainties in estimated temperatures due to ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of employing multiscale observation techniques in eco-hydrological research over heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing multiscale observation techniques can lead to a better understanding of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. These techniques provide comprehensive data at various scales, enhancing the ability to investigate complex interactions such as oasis-desert dynamics. This approach can improve the accuracy of models like the TSEB model, leading to more reliable estimates of evapotranspiration components and energy fluxes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of implementing a multi-scale observation experiment for evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces in eco-hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives of implementing a multi-scale observation experiment for evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces are to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes in such areas. This is achieved through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data, as demonstrated in the HiWATER experiment.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use high-resolution thermal cameras and stable isotopes for validating evapotranspiration estimates in agricultural areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to use high-resolution thermal cameras and stable isotopes for validating evapotranspiration estimates to obtain accurate measurements of soil and canopy component temperatures. These measurements help better validate the evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates, particularly in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, where traditional methods might not provide accurate results due to environmental complexities.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of using a hierarchical sensor network and remote sensing techniques in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert interactions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The significance of using a hierarchical sensor network and remote sensing techniques lies in their ability to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert interactions effectively. This approach allows for comprehensive data collection across different landscapes, enabling a better understanding of the interactions and processes occurring in these complex environments, as part of the HiWATER experiment.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in processing eddy covariance flux data collected from a heterogeneous landscape, ensuring its accuracy and reliability for further analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing of eddy covariance flux data involves several steps, including removing outliers, correcting for time delays, performing coordinate rotation (secondary coordinate rotation), frequency response corrections, ultrasonic virtual temperature corrections, and density corrections (WPL correction). Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is conducted, primarily testing for atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity characteristics. Specific data are removed if the instrument malfunctions, during rainfall events, or if data loss exceeds certain thresholds.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model applied to estimate evapotranspiration components in complex agricultural settings, and what are the data collection methods used to support this application?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The TSEB model is applied by using soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs. Ground-based measurements, including meteorological parameters and turbulent fluxes, aid in partitioning evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration. Observations are collected every ten minutes and include data such as air temperature, wind speed, humidity, and radiation. The soil and canopy component temperatures are calculated using thermal images and classified into soil and canopy pixels to estimate latent heat fluxes and validate the model against ground measurements.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the integration of eddy covariance systems and thermal infrared cameras enhance the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of eddy covariance systems and thermal infrared cameras enhances the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements by providing detailed observations of turbulent fluxes and radiometric temperatures. This combination allows for precise partitioning of latent and sensible heat fluxes and accurate calculation of soil and canopy component temperatures, which are crucial for reliable evapotranspiration estimates, especially in strongly advective conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why are there challenges in using composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions for estimating evapotranspiration?
Expectation.Answer: Composite temperature separation approaches face challenges in arid regions because errors in derived component temperatures are primarily caused by image classification errors. These errors vary with vegetation abundance, leading to inaccuracies in estimating soil and canopy temperatures, which are critical for determining evapotranspiration. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance can also lead to uncertainties in temperature estimation.

Expectation.Question: Why might the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model have limited application in real landscape conditions?
Expectation.Answer: The TSEB model might have limited application because it requires parameters and observations that are not readily obtainable from operational satellite- and ground-based data. The model is complex, involving multiple resistances that cannot be accurately calculated, which restricts its applicability in diverse landscape conditions where accurate surface flux estimation is necessary.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using eddy covariance systems for measuring turbulent fluxes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems for measuring turbulent fluxes is effective in heterogeneous landscapes as they are capable of capturing detailed temporal variations in fluxes. However, challenges exist such as incomplete energy balance closure which affects the accuracy of measurements. These systems are essential in providing the ground truth required to validate remote sensing models like the TSEB model.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the challenges of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces with regard to data availability?
Judgmental.Answer: The upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces is notably challenging due to the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER aims to address this by producing multiscale and multidisciplinary data through a hierarchically nested observation system, capturing interactions across different scales, thus providing a more comprehensive dataset for analysis.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential of remote sensing technologies like LiDAR and thermal imagers to improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration models in irrigated agricultural areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Remote sensing technologies such as LiDAR and thermal imagers hold significant potential for improving the accuracy of evapotranspiration models. They provide spatially extensive data that can be integrated with ground-based measurements to enhance model inputs and outputs. These technologies are crucial for capturing variations in surface temperature and vegetation structure, which are vital for refining estimations of soil and canopy component temperatures in models like the TSEB.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how challenges in multiscale observation are addressed in eco-hydrological studies.
Assertion.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses these challenges by using a hierarchical network of diverse instruments and sensors across different scales. This includes flux towers, remote sensing technologies, and ground-based measurements to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes comprehensively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: Progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. The HiWATER experiment was specifically designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to measure evapotranspiration in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the field, ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET). These temperatures were observed via a high-resolution thermal camera and used as inputs to the TSEB model, validated using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and eddy covariance (EC) measurements. Additionally, meteorological parameters and turbulent fluxes were measured using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz.
